tn.text: See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]].
The writer of Lamentations writes about the city of Jerusalem as if it is a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This phrase compares Jerusalem to a woman who is without protection because her husband has died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: She was a princess among the nations
tn.text: AT: "Other nations honored Jerusalem like they would honor the daughter of a king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "forced to become a slave"

The author describes Jerusalem as having emotions like a human being. The city also stands for her inhabitants. AT: "Those who live in her weep and wail." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "wails" refers to the sounds that a person makes when they "weep" loudly. AT: "weeps loudly." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
AT: "the people of Judah have been taken into a foreign land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
She is the kingdom of Judah who is described as a woman. She also stands for the citizens of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"does not find rest." AT: "is always afraid"
AT: "Everyone who was chasing her managed to capture her" or "Everyone who was hunting for her found her"
AT: "when she was desperate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The author speaks of the roads that lead to Zion mourning as if they were human beings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"the feasts that God told them to celebrate"
The word "her" refers to Zion. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"is bitter" or "is despairing"

tn.ref: Her adversaries have become her master
tn.text: "Zion's adversaries rule over her"
"her enemies become rich" or "her enemies are going great"
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.

tn.ref: Beauty has left the daughter of Zion
tn.text: AT: "Everything that was beautiful about the daughter of Zion is destroyed"
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: like deer that cannot find pasture
tn.text: The princes are compared with deer that have nothing to eat. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
A deer is a medium-sized, grass-eating animal that is often hunted by humans for food. It is also a beautiful animal to look at.
AT: "but are not strong enough to run away from"
AT: "the person that is pursuing them"

tn.ref: In the days of her affliction and her homelessness
tn.text: AT: "during her affliction and her homelessness" or "When Jerusalem is afflicted and homeless"
AT: "Jerusalem will remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"wealth"
AT: "in the past" or "before this disaster happened"

tn.ref: When her people fell into the hand of the adversary
tn.text: Here the word "hand" refers to the army of the enemy. AT: "When the adversary conquered and captured her people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"there was no helper for her"

tn.ref: saw her and laughed at her destruction
tn.text: This means that they were glad and mocked Jerusalem when it was destroyed.
AT: "because she was destroyed" or "while they destroyed her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

This describes Jerusalem as a person who sinned, while it also stands for the inhabitants of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: scorned as something that is filthy
tn.text: According to Old Testament law, a woman was ritually unclean during her monthly bleeding. "Jerusalem's sins have made her filthy and unclean, and therefore she was unacceptable before God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Jerusalem is described as a woman whose private parts have been shown to everyone to shame her. AT: "her naked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
AT: "Her downfall was astonishing" or "those who saw her destruction were surprised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings are that 1) the author of Lamentations now talks directly to Yahweh or 2) Jerusalem is described as talking to Yahweh like a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
AT: "Pay attention to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "has taken possession of" or "has stolen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"wealth"
The word "She" refers to Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The word "you" refers to Yahweh. This means the author or the city is still speaking, after starting in [[:en:bible:notes:lam:01:08|1:9]].
The word "her" refers to Jerusalem who is described as if she were a woman. AT: "her inhabitants" or "the people of the city" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"wealth"
AT: "to save their lives" or "to restore their stength"
Here Jerusalem begins to speak directly to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by?
tn.text: This is an accusation of the people who walk past Jerusalem and do not care for it. It has the form of a rhetorical question to sharply rebuke them. AT: "All you who pass by should care more for my affliction!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here Jerusalem continues to speak, but now to people who pass by. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Look and see if there is anyone else's sorrow like the sorrow that is being inflicted on me
tn.text: The implication here is that there is no one else has suffered as much.
These words share similar meanings. Together they invite the reader to understand by seeing that no one has suffered so much. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: the sorrow that is being inflicted on me
tn.text: AT: "the sorrow that Yahweh is inflicting upon me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: on the day of his fierce anger
tn.text: AT: "when he was fiercely angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he has sent fire into my bones
tn.text: In this passage "he" refers to God and "my" to Jerusalem, who still speaks to other people as if it is a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: has sent fire into my bones, and it has conquered them
tn.text: AT: "has sent a painful punishment into my inner being, and it has destroyed me" or "has sent a destructive punishment into the middle of Jerusalem, and it has destroyed the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: given me over into their hands
tn.text: AT: "let my enemies defeat me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: my mighty men who defended me
tn.text: In this section Jerusalem is still described as a woman talking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"strongest soldiers"

Here the enemy army attacking Jerusalem is spoken of as if it were a meeting of people who have come together in order to accuse and condemn someone. AT: "an army"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
men at the strongest time of their lives

tn.ref: The Lord has trampled ... in the winepress
tn.text: Here the judgment of God is described as if Jerusalem were grapes on which he had trampled in order to squeeze out the juice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. The word "virgin" suggests that this woman is pure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is still Jerusalem speaking as if it were a woman, now having the emotion of sadness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Zion has spread her hands wide
tn.text: Zion is like a person that lifts up her hands to ask for help. Here Jerusalem no longer speaks herself, but the author describes Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
AT: "the people around Jacob" or "the nations surrounding Jacob"
Here the word "his" refers to Jacob.
Here Jerusalem begins to speak again, as if it were a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
AT: "see how extremely sad I am" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: My virgins and my vigorous men
tn.text: AT: "so many of my people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:lam:01:15|1:15]].
AT: "they betrayed me"
AT: "to save their lives" or "to restore their strength"
Jerusalem continues to talk about herself as if she were a woman, but now talks directly to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The word "churn" means to move around violently, normally in a circular rotation. This does not mean literally, but it is how it feels. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my heart is disturbed within me
tn.text: AT: "my heart is broken" or "I am extremely sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The sword stands for the enemy, and "takes" means "kills". AT: "the enemy kills" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: inside the house there is only death
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) in the house, everyone is dying or 2) the house is like a grave.
Jerusalem continues to speak like a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here the word "you" refers to Yahweh.
